snippet: The “tomb sweeping” festival known as Qingming, reinstated as a public holiday in 2008, has relatives flocking to cemeteries to pay respect to ancestors by burning money.
abstract: Beijing Journal; residents of Beijing celebrate 'tomb sweeping' festival known as Qingming, in which living pay respects to departed ancestors by tidying graves and burning paper offerings so that spirits can afford good afterlife; banned by Communist Party in 1949 for its feudal links, Qingming is undergoing resurgence.

byline.contributor: Yuan Ren and Shi Da contributed research from Beijing, and Sue-Lin Wong from Fuzhou, China.

lead_paragraph: The “tomb sweeping” festival known as Qingming, reinstated as a public holiday in 2008, has relatives flocking to cemeteries to pay respect to ancestors by burning money.

headline.print_headline: Festival’s Resurgence Has Chinese Sending Manna to the Heavens
headline.seo: New Interest in China for ‘Tomb Sweeping’ Festival
headline.main: Festival’s Resurgence Has Chinese Sending Manna to the Heavens
